question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Question 1-3 are short-answer
questions. Put your answer in the box provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answer as much as possible}. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct
answer placed in the box. \textbf{Show your work}, for part marks.

If $\displaystyle x\sin(\pi x) = \int_0^x f(t) \ dt$ where
$\displaystyle f$ is a continuous function, find $\displaystyle f(4)$.
sols:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
\frac{d}{dx}\int_0^x f(t) \ dt = f(x),\end{align*}

so differentiating both sides gives

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
x\pi \cos(\pi x) + \sin(\pi x) = f(x)\end{align*}

At $\displaystyle x = 4,$ we have $\displaystyle f(4) = 4\pi$
hints:
How can we isolate $\displaystyle f(x)$? What operation can we perform
to get rid of the integral?
